value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">9</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-anon" key="Anon">Anon</rs> has emerged 
            <choice>
              <sic>suffievcntly</sic>
              <corr>sufficiently</corr>
            </choice> from the forests and the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">floods to let us see a rough outline of a human shape.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He has a dog and a garden. He has books; and he digs in</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the earth. His name is of no great moment. It may be</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Harrison; or it may be <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#past" key="Pastons">Paston</rs>. There is very little to dis 
            <choice>
              <sic>dis</sic>
              <corr>distinguish</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>tingusih</sic>
              <corr>distinguish</corr>
            </choice> one from the other. He has no 
            <choice>
              <sic>exr ssion</sic>
              <corr>expression</corr>
            </choice> on his 
            <choice>
              <sic>fae</sic>
              <corr>face</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He conveys to us chiefly what his eye sees, what his body</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">feels. He sees 
            <choice>
              <sic>ngland</sic>
              <corr>England</corr>
            </choice> very clearly. He sees</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">its 
            <choice>
              <sic>emptines</sic>
              <corr>emptiness</corr>
            </choice>; ; he conveys the scarcity of people; the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>predominace</sic>
              <corr>predominance</corr>
            </choice> of individuals. The <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-eliz" key="Elizabeth I">Queen</rs> is the dominant</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>fogure</sic>
              <corr>figure</corr>
            </choice>. He can count her 
            <choice>
              <sic>posses ons</sic>
              <corr>possessions</corr>
            </choice>-- a few ships; a few</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">great 
            <choice>
              <sic>hous s</sic>
              <corr>houses</corr>
            </choice>. He watches her 
            <choice>
              <sic>progeresses</sic>
              <corr>progresses</corr>
            </choice>. She is 
            <choice>
              <sic>parliemtn</sic>
              <corr>parliament</corr>
            </choice>,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">press, society, law and order. But the man who sees this</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the individual, is still cumbered and stiff. Writing is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">still an art that requires great ceremony. What you make</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">with the pen is separate from what you say with the tongue.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Only a few years back words were written 
            <choice>
              <sic>elbaorately</sic>
              <corr>elaborately</corr>
            </choice> in</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">lustrous ink upon valuable parchment; and the leaves,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">bound together, were chained to the lectern and read,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">by a few, in great physical discomfort,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">on hard 
            <choice>
              <sic>neches</sic>
              <corr>benches</corr>
            </choice> in the cold. Even now, when words are printed,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the great public is not the reader, or the paymaster.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Written words must please a single man in the first place,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">must find its way into some noble room, where the nobles</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and the gentry, have 
            <choice>
              <sic>lisure</sic>
              <corr>leisure</corr>
            </choice> after hunting, after</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">seeing their estates, and 
            <choice>
              <sic>contrlling</sic>
              <corr>controlling</corr>
            </choice> their servants,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to to pick up a book and read its history or sing its song.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">For Words must tell stories; or they must sound to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the ear. For the nobles had their music; they played tunes</l>
